speaker: CM
transcript: The good thing about moleculars are that they're more selective for single things and you can tune them but then the bad thing is there are issues with stability and and things like that, leeching, stuff like that. But I think a lot of people because they've usually worked in an organics, a lot of people discount them and that's a very fair criticism, but you can mimic organic environments by using relatively cheap polymer materials. In terms of controlled transport of water and protons and stuff. And I think I don't think that's been figured out because I don't think a lot of people look at that because a lot of people that would be well poised to look at the discount molecular systems because of the problems that they have.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker explains the advantages and disadvantages of molecular systems, including their selectivity and tunability, but also issues with stability and leeching.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: The speaker supports their claim about the dismissal of molecular systems by mentioning that many researchers have experience in organics and therefore discount molecular approaches.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: The speaker points out a flaw in the current research approach, which is the discounting of molecular systems due to stability issues, but also suggests a potential solution by mimicking organic environments with polymers.

speaker: AB
transcript: What about enzymes? Have people does anyone here know about using enzymes for this? And also I'm going to throw one other thing out as I'm kind of frantically taking notes. And that is in order to drive down costs using like single atom catalyst where you have a more expensive atom that's kind of embedded in a cheaper material.

speaker: EM
transcript: So I I have a collaborator who's looking at enzymes for CO2 reduction. I don't do it because they don't let me play with proteins. But she does it and shows that it works. Um and I think that there is some work out there in this space.

speaker: VV
transcript: And I can maybe comment on uh the single atom stuff. We have a very large RFI program that's essentially going after that exact question. So could we open up uh new materials that we would have not been able to do? And and there are two things that happen with single atom. One, it it attacks two things at once, which I think makes it an very exciting material set. It it first attacks the cost question like you pointed out, um actually. And then the second thing it actually attacks is it it brings out new ways of making materials look like other materials, right? So meaning that because you have a single atom, it behaves very differently than the bulk atom. Right? So you can suddenly make like and I guess I mean um you know, you know, this is sort of known in the molecular world, but uh you know, I guess the heterogeneous catalysis is catching up to it, right? That uh that you suddenly have one, you know, iron becoming like platinum or or or like gold. And and so then you can have cheaper single atoms even uh that give you the same sort of functionality. And the design space now is almost unlimited, right? You can now do single atom alloy catalyst. So like like two atom alloys. Um and then and of course whatever is the host uh support uh that is hosting that single atom anchor. Um and I think now uh it's at the point where the single atom density. So that density question that is problematic in the in the bio world is now actually largely solved. Like you can get these single atoms to be isolated in pockets that are not too far off and get sort of densities to be uh very high. So in terms of material set, I think um single atom and single atom single alloy atom SAA uh or Single atom alloy, yeah. single atom alloy, yeah. Single atom alloy, those are I think very exciting material sets where I think there's almost you know, no no picture on on the CO2 reduction.

speaker: MH
transcript: One thing that I think like to go back to the prompt, um which is um yeah, there are two hubs of. But to go back to the prompt which is like how do we move toward a complete picture of CO2 reduction. One thing that I just wanted to like synthesize from the discussion of the alloys and the single atom catalyst and enzymes and proteins is that what we're basically saying is and also I think they're really good point to make sure to highlight Ashley from that Provine basically mentioned is we need industrial relevant benchmarking metrics that can be applied to any catalyst system. Um and so maybe it's turnover number or maybe it's dollar per active site of a catalyst or maybe it's um but like I think that's something that is necessary because without that like without benchmarking all these different catalysts and types of catalysts are um it's really hard to compare them, right? Um and so I think that that's um it's something really hard to we don't even do that when we compare thermal catalytic systems and electro catalytic systems and I would argue that it's actually quite easy to compare thermal and electro catalytic, but then we don't then we don't we definitely don't do it when we start to look at biocatalysis and um and these other um you know, enzymes and you know, different routes. And so I think that's really necessary to start guiding um what directions are are likely to succeed.

speaker: CM
